message: Another shameless plug: I published another article on Toptal.
story: Ahmed Al-Amir shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Android Customization: How to Build a UI Component That Does What You Want
caption: toptal.com
description: Default Android UI components get the job done, but what if they aren't exactly what you want? Good news! The Android UI is easily customizable. In this article, Toptal developer Ahmed Al-Amir demonstrates how to build a custom calendar component, using techniques that will unleash you from the shac…

data.message: Very nice and you know what you have unique way than any other article i have ever read. :)
Thanks man, really appreciate the feedback

Looking awesome!
Can you talk to us a bit about the hiring process there? I talked to them but had a few weeks of pneumonia after initial interviews and never got to check the tests or follow up with them after that.

Mohamed, the hiring process is tough but straightforward:

1- First a screening interview, to verify your application and make sure you speak proper English, etc. Nothing technical at this stage. 

2- Then you are given an online test; three programming problem that you are required to solve in 90 minutes. This one is tough, but you are not expected to get a full score, they are rather testing your "problem solving abilities".

3- The next step is an online interview, through which they will review your test result and require you to solve two more problems with them over-watching/discussing it with you.

4- The final step is an assignment, usually one week long (two if it is specially hard). The assignment differs according to how you define your expected position (frontend, backend, mobile, etc.). This assignment will be heavily inspected for design and code style.

5- After that, congratulation, you are one of the best 3% developers in the word, as per Toptal advertisement :D

Aha. Quite similar to Readify's process (a test that's now automated, HR interview, tech interview with live debugging test), where we used to call it top 5-10% of the world, except we stopped using that wording because 'how can you tell? How can anyone even measure that?)
They have this silly diagram that justifies the "3%" they claim. Young people overtaken by success, هاح :D
